dad here and husband of a gamer mom my wife of years got into video games as a way to connect with our boys now and started with gamecube mario or zelda and then ps games like lego star wars minecraft in it's beta phase she played them as a kid * we are both gen x do yourself a favor don't judge the next generation based on one from years past though many things will be similar there will be numerous important differences playing age appropriate games together and sharing time also offers you the opportunity to impart life lessons casually so that it never feels like a lecture my wife has played every elder scrolls game and is playing skyrim as i type this you are not depriving your kids of anything just because you're a gamer our kids still game even though one lives halfway across the country and they both turned out better than okay you don't have to give up the things you love just because you have children

it’s important to teach your kid that moms can do all kinds of things yes cook and craft but also listen to metal and game and play the drums that shit is cool and also it’s not don’t get sucked into those ridiculous gender roles of our parents and grandparents don’t be ashamed of your interests and hobbies your kid wants to do whatever you’re doing because of you if you want to teach the kid crafts do some crafts together you don’t have to be a pinterest mom to go buy a birdhouse kit or construction paper and glue and googly eyes at hobby lobby if you want to teach the kid to bake or cook do it together if that means refrigerated cookie dough bought at walmart or scratch made lemon meringue pie do what works for you have fun if you want to teach the kid how to drum or which finnish metal bands are the best spend some time with them playing and listening and debating take them to a concert help them find their interests and passions and be open to whatever they want to do not just what you do or what you or your parents or society thinks they should do try things together and have fun

im a dad year old and month old boys not a mum but am a gamer and i sort of wrestled with this too i came to video games later in life and my childhood was very outdoorsy and i'd really like the same for my kids having said that video games have been a bit of a saviour for me as i'm sure you know parenting babies can be a crippling emotional mess at times the thing i dont see people talking about a lot is that its almost impossible to think about other things while you're playing videogames turning your brain off or focusing on something that's not parenting is such a gift some days i think a trap a lot of parents fall into myself included is suddenly viewing their lives through what is good for their kids but you were a person in the world before you kid came along and you need to do things for you as long as youre not endangering your child its ok for you to have a thing just for you and with your partner i wish my wife played videogames it would be a way to do something together that we both enjoy at home and spend fun time together something that's pretty hard in covid toddler times parenting is a lot of guilt in my experience but try not to feel bad about doing things that are just for you; being a more fulfilled person will translate into being a better parent

my kiddos are still little so i can’t totally vouch for how they’ll turn out but i basically grew up playing video games i’m and like many other older millennials am obsessed with technology i played video games or chatted on instant messenger lol pretty much my whole childhood—i’m tattooed love most genres of music from rock to pop to edm spent years in the military and am now a college professor working on my nd master’s degree you never quite know what will happen but i think it’s our job as parents to let kiddos experiment and find their own way as others said letting your kids see you have interests other than cooking and cleaning helps them see you as a “real” person and provides fun bonding experiences i think video games had a very positive influence on my ability to strategize think outside the box communicate take an interactive approach to reading learn to love learning and navigate gender stereotypes i can’t wait til my littles are old enough to play video games with me 🤩

year old gamer nerd mom here also love punk rock going to concerts have multiple tattoos and piercings i also happen to love crocheting cooking and baking i have kids now ages with only the younger two living at home i was actually playing an mmo when i went into labor for the first time we’ve all husband included played games ranging from computers xboxes playstations & nintendo’s we currently have an xbox ps wii switch gaming laptops and a gaming desktop i never really placed limits other than chores and schoolwork first and all my children are well adjusted and did well in school currently oldest is graduating with a bachelors degree in psychology middle child is getting certificates in welding and working and my youngest just graduated from high school last year and is working towards a business degree all still game to some extent some more than others what i am saying is be yourself that’s the best thing you can do for your kids let them be themselves and encourage them to do so heck we are a punk rock family and my son went through a phase where he listened to only country music we joked that it was his way of rebelling lol

my wife and i play video games over the last few months my boys and have watched me play through super mario odyssey in one hour chunks on a saturday morning they love it when i finally completed the game my year old burst into tears and eventually managed to tease out of him he was sad because we wouldn't be able to watch mario anymore they both also love watching my wife play stardew valley and get really into helping direct the action on the farm eldest has minutes screen time a couple times a week when he's been well behaved and he likes to play mario kart mostly i even wrote a video game specifically for my kids with the characters in the game being their bedtime teddies one has to rescue the other he loves it and chooses it for his screen time frequently so long as you set boundaries and explain that games are fun but they absolutely do not come before more important responsibilities you're fine we take pains to explain that mum and dad don't play video games every day it's something fun we do every now and again when we have time not an obsession so long as your relationship with your hobbies is healthy and the hobbies themselves are appropriate like i wouldnt be playing doom eternal or skyrim around them haha sharing this with your kids can only be positive both my wife and i are big power metal fans so kamelot and sonata arctica are blasting in the car most trips my son's sing along to manowar i think kids will grow up and normalize whatever their situation is make these things a bonding experience for the family these are your little traditions and routines and this is what they'll look back fondly on when they're older not man my mom was weird

you're amazing this is a great comment i had to claim my free award just to give it to you it's crazy that this seems to be somewhat of a new concept and that traditional parenting roles seem to be changing much more quickly in our generation than perhaps they have in years i think you're right that great moms can come in all shapes and sizes and don't have to fit a cookie cutter parenting model ops post clearly reflects that some have trouble with this concept because it deviates from what parenting was in previous generations my hope is that this new way of parenting has a positive impact on our children and allows them to be who they want to be as well and makes being able to freely be different from the average person the norm rather than the exception i can't imagine how much differently i would have turned out if it wasn't pounded into my head that moms do this and dads do this i like to think i do a good job being an active father but sometimes i fall into more traditional roles as a husband which is a sin because my wife works just as much and just as hard as i do we all need to do a lot of recalibrating on the way we think looking through the lens of thank you for your insightful comment i'm a year old late night gamer dad with young children whose partner despises gaming but i think it's important to feel confident that we can all parent how we feel comfortable and forget trying to conform to anyone else's expectations or old cultural norms

you’re not an idiot you’re a parent in the early oughts during a pandemic who is trying to figure out how to fill the day for your kid i definitely don’t recommend so much screen time for kids his age there are real world physically mentally stimulating ways to show him how to entertain himself with his imagination or to play together • reading together • listening to music and having a dance off • creating something together like paper planes with a penny to affect pitch • each if you draws a picture and you pass them to each other to color however you want • make a big loose scribble and have him decide what it looks like he then takes a thick marker and outlines the thing he sees in the scribble and colors it • you can take turns drawing and the other person guesses what it is • make a boat with a rubber band and pieces of wooden popsicle stick to twist in it to propel the boat forward in the bath and have a boat race • you can make a cardboard fort and draw furniture around in it or make a blanket fort and tape paper cutout furniture in it • write a story together sentence by sentence each of you switching back and forth so it’s written together and can lead anywhere • maybe play “lava” in the living room or find more board or card games to play you definitely want to get his body moving every day which will release endorphins the “feel good” hormones if he tuckers himself out each day he’ll sleep better and it can help reduce his funk i totally support his gaming especially since it includes socializing but being stationary in front of a screen for so long can breed depression and can lead to him losing sight of how to help himself feel better when gaming doesn’t always “fix” the funk when he’s older

i went through a phase in elementary school where i only hung out with boys i dressed in baggy boy clothes i had my hair short and i told my parents i wanted to be a boy i am so glad that happened in the s before anybody would have freaked out and blown it out of proportion i had been emotionally abused by women from a young age and became very shy where the girls my age wanted to gossip and role play and make friends in a way i wasn't comfortably with i preferred to be alone in nature or play simple competitive games because that was easier for me that just so happened to be more like how the boys played i didn't like feeling controlled by my mom's fashion choices for me which were girly and i idolized my older sister who was rebellious so i dressed like she dressed and i imitated my boy cousins who were like big brothers to me i wanted to feel closer to my step dad i think so i tried to engage in boy behaviors with him like playing basketball and going to baseball games it lasted a couple of years before i got bored with the trying of it and i just learned to like what i like and be who i am anyway there are complex and highly varied reasons a young child would say something like i want to be not what i am and it's not necessarily an identity crisis listen to your gut because nobody knows your child better than you at this age not even he does honestly

you're absolutely correct in that this is not healthy behavior you need to start setting limits with him we have only one tv and it's in our living room i don't allow our daughter to watch youtube because she will mindless scroll through videos for hours if we let her instead we will watch a movie together on the tv in the living room usually she loses interest in the movie and opts to go play with toys or color half way through i would start with clearly communicating to your son that he is to only have hours of screens a day after that time is used up he can do other activities such as play or draw and also tell him that since he broke his tv he will not be getting another one this will also teach him consequences it will be hard at first and expect a lot of tantrums but just stand your ground it will improve and will be much healthier for him in the long run your wife needs to be on board as well

just for some perspective op i am a mom to my oldest is my husband is in the military and i am alone a lot we have no family nearby nor any one who could babysit my kids get their fair share of tv time; but no one has a tv in their room no one has an ipad or tablet they have never played video games i can almost guarantee you that the problems in behaviour stem from a the screen time the kid is not getting an opportunity to become a kid there are so many great resources on instagram for you and your wife to check out hours outside is one account i follow that has a lot of information regarding the downsides to screen time for kids the good news is he is still young and can easily bounce back you guys can do this a little bit of good old fashioned research can perhaps help you guys with feeling good about the transition to less screen time i just want to elaborate i am in no way shaming or patting myself on the back we are allll literaly just doing the best we can good luck

since my spouse is a software engineer and we're both enthusiastic pc gamers we decided to bring our small human in to the tech echo system with his own pc before his own tablet phone we have our pcs all in our family office guest room so we're more able to monitor his usage plus it's less isolating than him sitting alone with a tiny screen inches from his face off in his own room we can see what he's doing we play games together or alone together sometimes etc think family lan party plus since he sees us working with computers and first helped us build ours and then actually built his with us he's developing an understanding for the 'behind the scenes' aspects of tech and media consumption we have parental controls on each element he has his own google account which is under ours and set as a minor we set it up and have the passwords his pc is password and pin locked with restrictions on when he can use it and for how long same with gaming services we've got his own accounts for things when allowable that we are the password account owners for and we curate them he has limited child accounts on our streaming services and we keep apprised of what he's engaging with obviously nothing is perfect for a while we were playing cat and mouse with him because he started getting up early and turning on the playstation to watch netflix and then to play so we had to add passwords so he started using the xbox so we had to add more passwords and then he started sneaking the switch and and and i expect we'll go through growth adjustment course corrections as he gets older he doesn't have access to youtube or social media at all yet and we won't be introducing it for years we both have sm but we don't share his photos and only sparingly post about him so he can decide the level his online presence when he's older we also make a point to engage each other and him over media we're using talking about it sharing etc so he is seeing us have a hopefully healthy relationship with it

okay so it looks like minecraft and roblox are two entirely different yet somewhat similar things * **minecraft** is a multiplayer game for pc android devices and consoles where players harvest resources and use them to create items and structures of varying complexity focus is on playful exploration and creativity with some mild social elements * **roblox** is an online game creation suite slash multiplayer environment best described as if unreal engine and second life had a child with a moderate to severe learning disability [see here] both seem harmless that said all online interactions your kids have need to be strictly supervised much like burning man is an awesome place where there's tons of cool shit to see and experience but you still wouldn't just let your kid run around completely unsupervised kids also should never go online without an adult paying close attention to what they're doing

how much and what do you allow for screen time for a year old what are you screen time rules for your year old i want to know if ours are normal we also have a year old with the same rules we do monday no screens tuesday thursday hour friday sunday hours child can watch netflix on their account which i’ve pre monitored play any video games that aren’t online minecraft mario spyro we don’t allow roblox or anything online with others other rules no closed doors if you are using electronics no screens after dinner how do yours stack up

all screens are in the lounge room he can play online games but we have regular chats re online friendships and interactions with people he meets online don’t do time limits as such but do do regular sporting activities both with family and in organised sports and he has to play card and board games do lego etc so a taking a make good decisions have a balanced approach he is very social on line and has made a really good group of friends we do listen in hence all screens in the lounge room rule so we know what is going on i will also play with him both in minecraft and roblox so have a very good idea of what he is doing and we always talk about online safety spending money and how you treat people you don’t know it’s mainly been positive with a few learning curves for everyone

computer screen experience for kids my kids are in first and third grade and so far they haven’t had much exposure to electronics they watch tv shows and movies on the weekend on streaming services on tv which we monitor but i keep screens off during the week including phones so they have never played anything on a tablet or switch or games like roblox or minecraft when we go on road trips any drive longer than hours they watch dvds in the car otherwise they enjoy listening to stories and podcasts for kids they do not use electronics of any kind for school they are doing well academically and i regularly read chapter books to them not to say they’re bored quite the opposite they do a lot of sports take music lessons and enjoy playing with friends swim in the pool and play with mud insects and more on our yard after school however as idyllic as that all sounds i can’t help feeling that perhaps they’re missing out on their development especially in this high tech world there are so many educational apps out there and they have zero computer or phone knowledge they don’t know how to use my phone and at all except to take pictures are they missing out tldr should i introduce more screen time to my kids

bring in a laptop install minecraft and play it with them lots of fun and you can casually educate them on online behavior they will learn how to type and there are also tons of software they can learn to use keep the phones and tablets out of their hands except occasionally calling or texting someone familiair

they're having a different experience from most of their peers but that doesn't mean they're missing out that said there are definite positives to *certain* video games the school computers at our school come preloaded with minecraft education and both my first and second grader play standard minecraft on my switch a few times a week for about minutes you should see the kind of creativity and problem solving the game encourages they love making things and showing off their creations minecraft is one game i'd recommend without hesitation stay far away from anything primarily online like roblox though also i don't have to tell you that if they truly have *zero* experience operating electronics of any kind then they'll definitely be at a temporary disadvantage when electronics are introduced at school but it should be only temporary i know this probably isn't super helpful if you *do* choose to introduce games do it with limits and a lot of research stay far away from online games because anything that introduced random people into the experience is an increasingly dangerous gamble but know that some video games like minecraft are legitimately positive experiences

games with lootbox mechanics or games that are only lootbox mechanics me and my wife have two kids as girl aged nearly and a boy of years old they both like playing computer games especially the boy who would prefer to do nothing else all day we've limited their screen time to an acceptable amount but i'm kind of worried about the kind of games he likes to play the games he's been spending most of his time with in the last few weeks have been what i'd call lootbox simulators pet simulator on roblox is the most recent one i've watched him play some and the core gameplay loop is click on a box so your pets will destroy open it coins come out and you can used the coins to buy eggs from which you get better pets rolled on a random loot table and then you go on to the next area where the boxes require more effort aka better pets to be opened and the cycle repeats i've got the feeling suspicion that this game is doing nothing else but feed a basic dopamine loop not unlike a skinner box and i'm worried that this is unhealthy for him i'm aware that games have gotten easier over time when computers made it in to my life when i was a tween games were pretty brutal by today's standards but this 'game' doesn't seem to offer any kind of challenge just the gambling aspect of getting a superior more rare pet from the eggs that you buy with the ingame currency\* his sister plays the game as well sometimes but most of the time when she plays roblox she spends her time roleplaying playing pretend though because she does play it's turning the game in to a contest for her younger brother making him want to play even more should i do something to stop him playing these kinds of games so much and if so what would be a good way \* you can use premium currency to buy better eggs but that's something we don't allow and our kids know how freemium games use this mechanic to lure people in to constantly spending money **edit ** i forgot to mention in all his other media habits tv youtube books he really favors the short and to the point stuff like grizzly and the lemmings which is basically a modern wiley e coyote cartoon let's play youtubers who hype up their reactions and books like storey treehouse all of those fall kind of in the same kind of 'dopamine rush' stuff

i think the habits he is developing there are definitely concerning i would suggest something like this sit down with the kids and talk about roblox these kind of games allow them to voice opinions freely; what is really cool what do they like dislike explain why gambling is addictive explain how adults use these type of games to negatively affect children tell them that roblox and other online games will be not allowed anymore and that exceptions for certain games might be made in the future i am thinking of more story based mmorpgs i think things like starstable or world of warcraft are fine let them know you understand that they are upset because it's immensely frustrating to get something taken away offer them a budget for offline games as an alternative your daughter might enjoy something like the sims perfectly harmless but get it on sale your son might like planet zoo if he likes animals or planet coaster

what are the cool but safe online games for < year old my yo son is very interested in roblox minecraft clash of clans etc but after trying these things there’s two things i’m concerned about * predatory micro transactions the slot machine nature of some these games is difficult to manage as a kid it’s hard to understand why we shouldn’t just buy of gems * chat the ability to connect with strangers and freeform chat is a concern family members have spoken about some very purile talk all the way to very suspicious predatory behaviour with their kids i’m at a bit of a loss to find something cool that is popular that allows him to start experience online fun any suggestions
if you're against minecraft there is nothing i can suggest you can play minecraft without being on a public server no micro transactions and mods galore it is a great game for bonding

with minecraft you just need to not play online it can be a pain to find a good server to play on and honestly i think public servers will be full of jerks i play on a private server one of my friends hosts if your kid and his friends all want to play minecraft you could look into getting them their own private server it doesn't cost too much and if all the parents of kids who want to play chip in it will cost almosy nothing a month

my year old plays roblox we have precautions in place but he also likes this site called abcya com you can't talk to other people on there or play with them so the social aspect isn't there if that's what he's looking for in roblox we have set up his account so no one can message him every time he wants to play a new title we check it over first most games have pretty strict rules about acceptable behavior and in my experience mods are pretty good about getting rid of those who can't follow the rules there is a running chat during most games that shows up in the corner of the screen but you can hide it bad or even suspect words are blocked with hashtags only once while watching the chat did i see someone say something racist and i was happy to see the other players jump all over that person and they were reported and removed from the game we haven't had any problems with roblox but we also keep up on what he's playing and don't allow him to privately message people or anything we check his account every few days you can spend money on roblox but without your credit card he can't and there's plenty to play and do without paying for it i don't know as much about minecraft but our local library has their own server kids can play while there or can access from home and it's tightly controlled behavior wise you might see if your library has something similar

my kids are we play a lot of minecraft online and not and we also play roblox they get the ideas of what video games to try out based on what they hear from schoolmates and what they see on popular youtube channels of other gamers we have some boundaries first off their screens can be seen from my desk i don't make a deal out of looking at what is happening on their screens but if i see something that border on inappropriate i make a subtle suggestion hey that looks like something an adult might watch and they know to change channels or do something else i know i cannot stop them looking at inappropriate stuff i can only guide them; if they want to be naughty or sneaky it can happen anywhere at school a friends house the library computers my approach is to guide but be open to questions and support at all times the do get friend requests but we've already had the talk about how only people they have met in real life can be accepted as virtual friends i also point out that virtual micro transactions are worthless and the stuff you buy can be played for they do get steam vouchers occasionally and i tell them to spend wisely or lose out i usually select their games or guide their choices and they have a good idea already of what is 'adult content' versus what is 'kid appropriate' something else you might run into soon email confirmations for games and distributions eventually you will get tired of having your youtube channel filled up with roblox promo content and you will have a hard time registering your username and your kid's usernames on the same email address for some titles or services yep they have to have an email address of their own at some point i made a domain for my family and i manage the email i have it mirrored to my inbox and i can see what is coming and going before they do to reduce the spam overhead i chose a domain name that is uncommon and i do the registering of products to be sure the check boxes for 'send more stuff' are not set in the future minecraft will have it's own currency system i understand this move it to compensate plug in and map developers better you can check out the r minecraft sub for updates and a better explanation i go there often for build ideas or resource pack announcements there is a sub r mcservers in which you can search for family oriented minecraft servers or you can just make your own it's not too difficult

minecraft was definitely the most popular with my boys we turned the chat options off with minecraft on a laptop but my sons played with their friends by being connected via skype on an ipad so it was like their own space within a public server another favourite was rocket league which is multiplatform and doesn’t require any chatting
honestly the online option for most games is not a good idea for children and even on okay games they shouldn't be without supervision

if you want something different you could download world of warcraft you can play up to level for free you can't send in game mail make a party or private chat on the free version there is a general chat that's moderated but you can just shut it off my year old loves making new toons exploring doing the low level quests and trying to help other players it's fun to watch her try and communicate with other players using only emotes roblox has been great for her i was against it for awhile but the game has good parental controls we have the private messaging shut off but left the general chat turned on she has to play it out in the living room so we can monitor her behaviour and the other players behaviour it's been great she gets to practice her spelling and learn to interact with people online in a pretty darn safe environment someone did call her a newb it made her sad even though she didn't know the meaning of the word we explained what it means how it can be said in a mean way or in a joking way she learned about how you can't express sarcasm online very well she took a break from the game for a bit and then started playing again i know you want to keep your kid safe online the best way to teach them is to let them have online experiences now in places that are easy for you to control and monitor

for the first several years of my son's screentime we made him 'pay' for it we had a poker chip system where he could give us a differently colored chip to get red minutes of video games blue hour of video games or white minutes of tv we provided a weekly allowance of chips and he could earn more based on good behavior or completing chores i totally recommend it in case you need something like this it teaches economics time management and respect we don't need to use them anymore but he remembers our updated rule is the rule no electronics before or after the daytime 's this helps mitigate the urge to break out the tablet before school in the mornings or way too early on weekends as far as video games are concerned i recommend having as clear a line of communication about being in control as possible **the moment you suggest it's time to turn off the video game it needs to turn off ** conversely as an adult i recommend *being sensitive to their needs as a gamer* make sure you check that they've _had an opportunity to save_ without abruptly turning off video game systems cuz that kind of stuff can stick with a kid for their whole lives i still remember my mom setting me back hours of zelda progress my son was raised on video games he taught himself to read from pokemon and is the best reader in his school feel free to let me know if you have any questions about games and kids

you are going to get a lot of responses from the screen time fascists here so here is something maybe closer to you… remember the virtual worlds our children are engaged in are amazing and they are also social outlets if when you were a child you had access to an amazing fantasy world that you and your friends could play in wouldn’t you be there all the time in our house we do a few things first we have daily chores so it doesn’t matter if you would prefer to be in your virtual world in your room you have to come out and do your chores second we try to create opportunities to do some things that are cool and fun and competitive we have one kid who really likes sports and she will leave her room to go play softball any day we have another kid who likes to go outside as long as somebody’s outside with him third we encourage some of the non gaming behavior we found out that two of our kids like to go on walks around the neighborhood and talk to each other so we adopted it made it kind of a rule hey guys it’s time to go on your walk and they do

kid won't practice but won't quit just want to vent a bit we have trouble getting our son to practice his piano he is pretty good at it but in the past year it has been tough he likes playing it but there is always other things that he wants to do like roblox playing with the neighbours reading his minecraft zombie that he read in year he used to be more proactive in his younger days and improve very quickly when he was in kindy and year it slowed down a bit in year and but we understand because school is more intense but last year and this year it is always a chore to practice he would probably do it once per week he still enjoys playing but it seems that there are just other things he wants to do he would say he will practice but instead of heading to the piano he would divert to talk to my wife and then get distracted by other things if i am firm and insisting that he head over now he would say he is already heading over and then gets emotional and in a bad mood as if i have falsely accused him of something then if minor conflicts happen during practice and sometimes he really ticks me off and i can be mad at him it can escalate very quickly to loud incessant crying it does make me think that this is more of a power trip then unwillingness to practice similar with other stuff as well he was already moody when he came to practice today then he needed to check something i let him and he returns then plays for a few minutes and says he is tired and wants to go to bed i was a bit annoyed so i told him that he needs to play through the piece a couple more times before he can go to bed his usual bed time is not for another minutes i did raise my voice and i told him i am upset with him and this lead to him crying on top of his lungs for minutes until my wife came and told him to go to bed but on a good day like two days ago he worked hard he wanted me to sit with him and we go through a piece he is learning and he did well he also listened to my advice as well my wife has told him this year that he is wasting money having the lessons since he won't practice and did not improve she said a few harsh words as well which i think was not appropriate she said she was embarrassed that he did not improve for a year and that his friend who was way behind him had caught up already but every time we bring this up he is very insistent on that he wants to play and begs us not to stop the lessons i have learnt piano at a young age and i do know what it feels like when practicing is a drag however i did go through with it because i like playing and when i was good enough to play what i wanted it is no longer a chore to practice but at that time i was addicted to playing really professional pieces those ones that top pianist play at concerts so i improved rapidly my current thought is that i will tell him that we should stop the lessons if he wants to learn he needs to show it piano is there so he can practice if he wants we won't have lessons again until he can demonstrate at least willingness to practice a few times a week i play the piano myself so i can help him if he wants i tried teaching him before but he is fairly resistant taking instructions from me sometimes so we went with external teachers i guess if i play more in front of him it may stimulate him a bit more to learn i guess both him and the little one does like to listen to me play the only problem is that my wife hates seeing me play because if i have time to play then i might as well use this time to do the dishes or catch up with work etc it is not like i play bad i am good enough to teach professionally and my friends who plays music all highly rate my music i have high level diplomas to prove as well as a result i hardly ever plays since we got married she does praise him when he plays he can do a good job when he puts his mind to it perhaps i can try slip a few music that he may like and see if he will do it more he is currently into music from some roblox games and also geometry dash which is a bit hard to put on piano but then i got to get it past the wife first i think she is a bit set on stopping edit just to clarify things what happened tonight is not usual at this household if he does practice normally either me or my wife if not busy will sit in the lounge to keep him company and help him out if he needs like play the left hand or right hand for him etc or record him play the pieces he think he got it right and also this is like the rd time he actually sat on the piano outside lessons in like weeks so we are not forcing him to practice everyday and earlier today he was playing with the neighbours and got upset cos other neighbour who seems to be celebrating something was not home so he can't ask them what's happening he gets lots of love and attention as well

from someone who was forced to practice from the age of and do all my grades by the time i was i hated the piano i hated music i just hated it all luckily an amazing music teacher came into my life who told my mum to back off let me learn to love music again and we started from the beginning playing music i loved don't shout at him ffs and let him practice on his own let him choose the music he wants to learn let him feel the joy of music and learning a peice of music and bringing it to life

you yell at him and yes you said today was an unusual occurrence but it also sounds like you get into “minor conflicts” during practice more frequently maybe not so minor to him your wife says “harsh words” to him your wife yells at you when you play i think part of what you’re seeing is your son responding to the family dynamics in this house but also maybe he shouldn’t be forced to practice piano if he doesn’t want to why are you so focused on him improving his skills he probably won’t end up playing piano professionally why can’t piano just be something he enjoys doing when he wants to

from your other responses your child is also playing the violin which he does practice *and* is in other extracurriculars stop pushing the piano let him know that you fully support him in pursuing his own interests at whatever level he wants to pursue them casual interest is valid quiting lessons and just playing around sometimes is fine never touching a piano or any other musical instrument again is fine picking it up again further down the line is fine and so on also you and your wife need to work on your communication skills with eachother and the kids as well as clear division of labor expection setting amongst you and your wife maybe some limited counseling sessions to deal specifically with that would be helpful my husband and i had similar issues though it was pre kids and ten targeted sessions worked for us

how long does he have to practice for or minutes or times a day also works and why not study some quatre mains pieces together that might be fun i feel like it might have become about power more than about the fun of making music he likes playing but it’s also normal for children to test their boundaries

hey there i also played the piano as a kid but resisted lessons and practice *a lot* i ended up continuing my piano education into my twenties and got the diplôme supérieur in the country i was living then and you know what i never really practiced all that much my technique was never really that amazing i mostly got by on passion and being into music and sheer confidence haha and the thing is somewhere along the way i discovered the reason i hated practicing those same goddamn bach pieces all day but also wanted my piano in my life is that what a really wanted was *to compose music * and the piano is an incredibly valuable available pathway to sit down and experiment with composition and improvisation and so on what does he like about the piano does he want to end up playing famous difficult pieces like you describe your own motivation being does he wants a way to express his feelings does he want to write his own music does he want to learn to accompagny like a vocalist or to play keyboard for a rock band does he want just enough mastery of the instrument to be able to connect to pop culture that way and interpret movie scores and videogame scores and stuff you'd be surprised how popular some people who just transcribe culturally relevant soundtracks into piano can be even when their performance technique is quite average; transcription is its own skillset what part of playing gets him ambitious and starry eyed he doesn't need to learn the piano in a rigid predetermined way just shape things around what interests and draws *him * and honestly he doesn't need to get good and work hard to deserve wanting to play

my son is a little younger he will not practice at home but loves his weekly lessons we decided that is enough for now and it’s not worth the battle eventually he will either decide he wants to practice for faster growth or he will lose interest entirely which ever is fine with us but right now he’s slowly building a skill and is having fun with it

i took piano lessons for years have been playing on and off for years now i'm not amazing at it but it's consistently brought me joy i genuinely don't understand what the problem is with continuing lessons even if he doesn't have time to practice outside of that he's still learning new things and keeping up with something he seems to enjoy the tips that others have given about providing music that he enjoys and modeling practicing yourself despite your wife's complaints are good and all but i don't agree with this implicit idea that the lessons are only worth it if he's good enough to go to competition or play professionally later on if you have the disposable income why not let him set the terms for how much to keep up with playing if he still likes to

imo kids should do musical instruments if they want to music is about expression if they aren't feeling it they shouldn't be forced just because you or any family member was good at it or likes it doesn't mean kid should do it sometimes they need us to decide it might be that he feels pressured to want to but the reality is he doesn't want to but doesn't want to let you down doesn't want to practice that's fine don't but you won't have lessons that are paid for if you aren't showing commitment got something else you want to do fine put in the commitment do the practice get ready on time and there's no issue my daughter does several activities one of which involves an early morning she wants to do the activity she has to get herself up and ready for it pack her kit bag too show commitment when she drags her heels i say i don't have to pay for or take her to any of her activities i can do my own thing or jobs at home or chill if she wants my efforts she has to show commitment and put in her part then i'm willing to do my part otherwise no these things are all privileges i don't force her to do anything that breeds resentment especially in a kid like mine maybe it works for other kids but not mine

if he already had a good foundation to build on i would skip lessons for now and set him up with a piano learning app he can use that on demand and learn to play any song he likes my husband and i learned piano growing up and my kids took online lessons during the pandemic but they hated having another extracurricular activity at a set time we recently got a new piano and got a piano app on the ipad now everybody can sit down and learn a new piece when they feel like it the app also comes with lessons you can take we use flowkey but there are many other apps too this system is so much more flexible and by choosing the songs you want to play everybody is way more motivated to sit at the piano whenever they want

imho he needs to play with other people like a band or something like that he needs to play with people who are better then him but have the same vibe try to group him with more people from his age and see what happens

the decision is on him but he will have to make the decision either he practices or he quits the lessons doesn't mean he can't play the piano without the lessons maybe be thinks if he quits he won't be able to play anymore maybe he wants to play whenever he wants and doesn't care much about the lesson

let the natural consequences be the measure of success if he doesn’t improve over his past performance then he is demonstrating in action that he is not interested enough in the subject to pay for further participation lessons if he does improve then continue with the lessons this is a model that will spill into just about anything he commits to sports extra curriculars college courses jobs… actions always speak louder than words so if he will decide through his own actions no matter what he says

that's why we are thinking of stopping piano he probably think it is a failure that we are stopping this my wife had told him earlier this year that it is probably best we stop lessons and just go casual on piano so he has one thing less to worry about he can still play and yes i am not proud of what i did tonight i should have just let things go and let him come off when he wants to i did apologize to him and will discuss with him about it in the morning too

normally my wife is very encouraging to him it was a one off burst and i don't think i did the best paraphrasing but she is trying to tell him that other people progressed while you did not put any effort and since you don't want to put in an effort then why not make it casual and go easier on yourself he has a lot to do already and we have great neighbour kids that he spends a lot of time with so one less commitment would be good for him he can still play and lessons can resume if he is serious about it

>she also did tell him that she was a little disappointed that he did not argue back that time what on earth she's *disappointed* that he didn't *argue back* what is going on with this dynamic op i think you and your wife need to have some serious conversations about the things she's saying to your son if you want your son to have a meaningful experience learning this instrument the whole family dynamic around practicing needs to be reframed i played piano for many years practicing is not always fun and i think that's normal and okay i think pretty much anyone who's studied an instrument seriously knows that it's never going to be a completely pain free experience and that doesn't mean it's a bad thing sometimes you have to sit down with the metronome and drill something over and over and it's boring and annoying and you'd much rather go play or watch tv but the *overarching experience* of learning should be rooted in joy he should learn pieces he loves to play and that allow him to express his own individual artistry he should feel excitement and pride and inspiration and motivation from the process of working hard and getting better these are invaluable lessons for a kid it doesn't have to be fun every single time he sits down to practice but it also shouldn't be driven by shame or guilt or pressure to be better than his peers to save his mother from feeling embarrassed for god's sake

no you're not sitting him down and forcing him but it seems like it's a very contentious issue i think maybe you should just say look put the piano lessons on the back burner would love to hear you practicing the piano let's pick some books of your favourite songs etc and you just play when you want to maybe learn some duets together and just bring the joy back

experience with video game consoles for year olds my year old has been talking about wanting a video game console playstation preferably for over a year now he says he wants to do this because it gives him something common with his friends in school who all seem to have these consoles and are constantly talking about playing sports games fifa madden nba k etc he wants to fit in and i'm sure he wants to play the games too he and his year old brother already have ipads with roblox minecraft and a few other games which i lock down heavily and restrict to pretty short time limits with screen time the ipads have been a mixed experience they were quite educational for a while but then evolved into basically daily fun my kids at present are always out playing in the neighborhood or with team soccer i am kind of leery of video game consoles i presume i can lock them down just like ipads to particular time limits and games i'm worried that inevitably as the kids get older they will become giant wastes of time i didn't myself have a video game console until university although i had computers that could play games before that i watch zero tv and like to be out and about but i also want to be somewhat open to what my kid tells me is important to him for those who have experience with introducing video game consoles in this age range what has gone right and or wrong

i had and still have numerous video game consoles played a lot as a kid and play a lot as an adult my daughter was introduced to gaming at a very young age but it's always been instilled in her that gaming comes last after chores after homework after extra curricular etc her free time is her own and she can choose to do as she pleases during that time as long as everything else is done we don't even have time limits just as i didn't when i was a kid she's a straight a student who is doing ap courses taking pre college courses and calculus overall just a really good young adult i firmly believe that there are more benefits to playing video games than there are negatives but teaching kids how to properly use their time on their own first is a necessity

i definitely would not get him a ps first of all they’re incredibly expensive to get for a kid if you or another adult in your household had one already and let the kids play it only under supervision that would be different but i would never buy one just for a child it’s also very definitively an adult oriented console the majority of the games available are not appropriate for kids and younger teens anything that is will be available on another platform and they notably do not have parental controls so you’d have to lock it away and supervise them while they play to make sure they’re not playing inappropriate games or are talking to strangers it’s *so easy* to talk to strangers on the ps online multiplayer is default turned on for a lot of games and the mic and speaker are built into the controller and since there aren’t parental controls you have no way to restrict that other than physically sitting there with them you seem very on top of your children’s online safety so i don’t need to tell you how dangerous that is for kids switch and xbox are better they’re far cheaper have parental controls and have a lot more age appropriate games the cross platform thing is a different story contrary to what some other people said out of those sports games fifa is the only one that’s cross compatible from ps and only with the xbox if you have a windows pc it’s also cross compatible with that so you wouldn’t even need a console if he wanted to play with his friends if i was you and if i had a pc i’d start there let him try fifa with his friends for a few months to test the waters maybe he’ll lose interest and you’re only out the cost of the game maybe he likes it but you notice it’s having negative effects in which case you’ll be able to stop it earlier and easier maybe he likes it and is able to regulate himself and use it responsibly at which point the topic of a console can be revisited emotional regulation at his age is definitely something to consider the number of kids i know who have rage smashed a switch or a controller is ridiculous so i would want to be sure my child could handle it before giving them something expensive to break

the switch lets you set limits on how long and how late the console can be played you can have either an alarm pop up or have the game force stop but you can adjust or override it from your phone with an app if you want to you can also whitelist games so only content you approve can be played you can prevent online chat and photo sharing as well the xbox has nearly the same the time controls are similar it’s also app based and you can set it up to require your approval to download a game or to add a friend with the xbox they can send a push notification to your phone to request more time but you can do it manually too [here is the switch game library ] [here is the xbox game library ] personally i think the switch is more kid friendly the xbox has games like gta cod resident evil etc which imo far far too many children and teens play given the content you can restrict what they’re allowed to buy of course but that temptation of “it’s right there if i could juuuuust steal mom’s phone for a second” will still be there most of the kid friendly content on xbox is multiplayer sports legos and minecraft the switch does also have gta cod etc **but** the balance of adult games to kid games is much better the switch has zelda games even the og ones if you subscribe pokémon animal crossing mario smash bros mario kart lego minecraft kirby and a lot more popular ones the switch does have fifa but you can only do online multiplayer with other switches not with xbox or ps or anything else tldr; parental controls are comparable between the two and you control them with an app on your phone the switch has more age appropriate games as well as games he can grow into the switch is also portable and good for car trips you can buy kids protective bumper cases for it the switch doesn’t have as many sports games as xbox and the switch doesn’t support cross console play

as a parent myself and someone who works with kids i see many different types of kids and situations and many times it comes down to finding the ones similar to you just like with adults not everyone meshes well or has similar traits there are many kids that randomly call out words or sounds from video games and the others that might see those kids as weird some that are really loud and some that are quiet some that are full of energy and some that barely exude any etc not sure your son's age but as they get older personalities develop more what used to be a situation where everyone could run around and pretend and play together is now becoming a who has similar interests and finds each other's company enjoyable if his friend isn't the kind of guy who randomly calls out video game references and finds that annoying in a friend that might not be the type of friend your son should have i hate to say that but people need to feel the friends they have and the people they're around like them and the way they are and vice versa i'm going through similar things as my son will be soon who tends to be a loud silly guy often who he himself randomly calls out references and i can tell what kids like that about him and are like that too and what ones are annoyed by that obviously the latter aren't going to be good friend material for his personality i'm trying to encourage him to not play with those who aren't nice to him basically those who would make someone feel bad for being who they are which unfortunately comes up everyone needs to find people they click with and if it means it's not that one friend from nd grade so be it he'll find the ones who accept him for him and are like him and enjoy his company

that’s a tough one ill say as a minecraft player that it’s very hit or miss what actually happens on a server some servers keep themselves clean others allow more vulgar behavior im not well versed in child psychology but if he’s already willing to talk to you you can probably show interest and get him going on about it enough that he’d reveal undesirable things without thinking too much about it also doesn’t hurt to ask him what the server’s name is and give it a quick google many servers have websites that list out their rules and all of that good opportunity to be reinforcing how to be safe and sane on the internet it’s a very valuable skill that could very well be helped by being ‘in it’ within reason

my almost year old also loves minecraft and i just recently started letting him play online he plays on the hypixel server which has a lot of rules to try to create a safe environment i’ve popped in and watched over his shoulder here and there and haven’t seen or heard anything inappropriate so far at one point he was also wanting to play “among us” and “fortnite” but i vetoed those mainly based on the fact that my high school students were playing those a lot at the time and i know what kind of language they use unfortunately he has a chromebook for school and so he has access to a lot of free to play browser based games that i’m not always around to supervise so far he has found some kind of fortnite esque game seems to be pretty limited though so probably not nearly as popular as well as a gaming called taming io which so far seems to be ok he’s even talked his little sister into playing that one with him occasionally i’d say watch him play or even play with him for awhile get a feel for the game or server to see if it’s appropriate if a game offers a way to turn off chat features that’s a great thing to take advantage of and talk to him about things he may encounter that you might not approve of for instance i expect my kids not to curse but i do occasionally and my mother swears like a sailor but they know those are words for adults and they shouldn’t use them

nobody really chats in the minecraft servers that my kids have been on it's a lot of repetitive mini games with presumably kids who can't type fast enough to actually have a conversation i do not allow voice chat or discord beyond that i make sure that my kids know what not to reveal name age address phone number etc and to let me know if someone seems to be prying or if i'm not around to close the game and play something else

comforting kids video games let me start by saying that i f do not care about video games i appreciate them as a form of art but playing them has just never made much sense to me i’m not particularly competitive and just don’t find them enjoyable that said my ex is an avid gamer and my son is now too during the week my son is with me my husband and my mom none of us play video games my son being probably isn’t the best gamer in the world and naturally he gets really upset when he loses a game or perceives that someone has “attacked” him he mostly plays roblox if that’s relevant the problem is that when he gets upset about something in the game i have no idea how to help or comfort him if this issue—losing a game something “unfair” happening—were to happen in real life i feel prepared to handle that i’m a teacher and talk kids through difficult experiences all the time but pretty much always in situations where we can observe the other party’s contributions and root our discussions in empathy and boundaries in terms of the game i have no idea who the other players are what their motivations are other than winning and just generally don’t have much to say besides “that sounds frustrating i’m sorry buddy maybe we should take a break from the game ” generally he shoots that idea down wipes his tears and gets back to the game every now and then he’ll come for a cuddle before doing the same i also don’t know if this level of emotion around a game is “normal” or if it signifies that maybe he shouldn’t be allowed to play them anymore he’s not throwing things or screaming in anger but he cries a lot losing is a part of life so i don’t think it’s bad necessarily to practice losing i just don’t know how to support him better or when enough is enough gamer parents out there—help please

how does your son display his anger at these games two of my kids have been in sports and they are big sore losers i had to learn to just let them have their emotions as long as they aren’t being destructive yelling cursing hitting etc kids are learning emotional regulation so it can be tough for them to get a blow like a loss and not get upset i think you’re doing a great job in encouraging him to maybe take or break and for validating his feelings the fact that he gets back on the game afterwards is great sounds like a resilient little guy

pulled from common sense media “roblox doesn't specify a minimum age users of any age can create and join groups chat and interact with others such an open approach can pose some risks to kids especially younger ones and though roblox has some safety precautions in place it remains a target for people with less than good intentions still because of the learning potential roblox offers common sense media rates it ok for users age + help your kids protect themselves by enabling privacy settings and teaching them how to be safe online ” in a nutshell i think roblox is a bit too old for a five year old if you are looking for age appropriate alternatives i really liked pbs org’s free games for kids they are age appropriate educational help teach strategy and are good starting blocks for little ones my five year old really enjoys the sesame street ones maybe check those out
roblox sucks at that age the best games are ones that are open ended and not a competition like minecraft or a the sims

i am educator parent gamer and pivoting into a career in educational software design imo is young for solo video game playing particularly if it’s an action game action games are the genre of game that test and strengthen hand eye coordination spacial reasoning and reaction time this is one of the oldest most popular and most anxiety inducing game genres playing with a parent is different and i think central to you issue it sounds like you son and his father have a play based bond whether it’s sports cards board games or video games play is a wonderful foundation for a relationship with a child it can also set expectations in a child that can confuse them when they’re not met in this case i suspect your son is not responding to the game itself but rather confusion over why you’re not displaying interest and understanding please don’t take this as a criticism of you everyone plays in their own way and it’s all good but the fact that you’re here asking the question shows that even though you don’t have the answers about the specific game you still want to answer your son’s needs i suggest play find your own way to play with him maybe you can draw him into your world and how you play how do you play think hard about that and how you can share your own way of playing with your son maybe you’ll be the one who has to budge and pick up a controller the good news is that you’ll find that as a year old female you are the demographic that the game industry want the most you belong to a fast growing demographic of game players and the market is flooded with games that marketers think you’ll like you may find other types of video games that you can bond with your son over i recommend the “point and click” adventure game genre these games are based on story frequently feature kid friendly graphics and characters and never put players in high pressure stressful situations they’re absolutely wonderful for side by side kid parent play talking through the character choices and story logic can be incredibly fun good luck i’m passionate about bringing kids and their adults closer together with games so i hope this helps if you’d like more recommendations or have questions i’d love to talk more

thanks for finding this we do have parental controls on and so far the chats haven’t been an issue because my son can’t read yet sometimes if he wants to say “hi” to others in the chat he’ll ask me to type out a short message for him i do often watch the games over his shoulder and so far i’m not worried about the content of the games we have a strict no shooting games policy and he knows that and follows it well because he is supervised my concern really is just that i don’t know how emotionally involved in the game he should be is it a bad thing that he’s so emotional over something that isn’t real and doesn’t have real life consequences

i would honestly like to play minecraft but there is a mental block for me that’s hard to explain i have trouble with coordination between my mind and game controls of any sort the closest i’ve ever been to making sense of the controls with any kind of video game was a vr situation like if i can physically act out what i want the character to do games are really fun otherwise i get a massive headache and the spins just trying to get from move forward —> use legs and walk to move forward —> use fingers to press this button it sounds crazy but it all comes down to being on the spectrum and generally having poor spatial reasoning 🤣 thankfully my little guy has a ton of very actively involved adults in his life with a wide variety of skills and interests he knows dad and uncle dan are the video game people stepdad is the sports and cartoons guy grandma is complex lego sets and puzzles and mom is in the garden or out in the tool shed

my year old wanted to play roblox and the only way we'd allow it was to download it on our phones and make an account and play alongside her she loves it i know she's safe and she's now so much better than me at it

managing screen time for multiple kids many devices i am desperately in search of a comprehensive solution for managing and limiting children’s screen time across a variety of devices i often feel like the kids spend way too much time on their phones tablets family laptops etc ￼￼ one is a macbook and the others are windows it is hard to manually track all this and because there are multiple kids it’s a nightmare an ideal solution would let me allocate daily screen time per kid and also define maximum length usage sessions on the more in demand devices the devices would have to know which kid is signed in to help track usages and enforce limits an added bonus would be a way to define max usage limits on specific apps like roblox or youtube i have tons of creative software for them to explore but they get sucked into low quality repetitive garbage on roblox way too easily i’m hoping some techie parents out there have discovered solutions for this especially ones that work across platforms like windows mac and ios even better if it also works for gaming consoles and kindle fire tablets but i realize there must be limits to what is possible ￼on closed platforms like those￼ any help or insight would be much appreciated thanks ￼

your best bet is to look for a solution at the wifi level controlling each device rather than each kid my parents have a system that lets them set a time for each device logged in and can override it to turn them off i will ask what it’s called but i’m uk based so not sure if it will be available where you are edit it’s called ubiquiti

i have a firewall device plugged into my router called firewalla its got parental controls that can block different sites games streaming services etc on a device by device basis some routers can do this too but i wanted the device for adblock mostly in apps my kid uses on my ipad and on my mobile phone when connected to wifi also got a vpn server out of it for using public wifi
so this blocks ads that pop up in games it drives me nuts how many ads push through the games that's why we don't watch cable tv either

meaningful activities with a year old kid hello my aunt died a few weeks ago and she left us with her year old son my cousin my uncle can't spend too much time with my cousin his son because he's busy with his business and he's also grieving my aunt's death a week ago my grandmother my uncle's mother also died so my uncle is a bit of an emotional wreck but he does try to spend quality time with my cousin every now and then my cousin has alternative caregivers one is a relative of ours but sometimes she's busy with household chores she can't give her full attention to my cousin the other caregiver is my other aunt who's my uncle's sister she occasionally plays with my cousin but because she's working from home she can't give her attention to my cousin oftentimes my cousin would videocall me or his cousins in his mom's side whenever i'm not doing household chores or not working from home i'd give him my full attention he's very clingy and whenever i visit their house and i have to go home afterwards he'd block my way and doesn't want me to go home i know he misses his mom so much and he knows his mom is never coming back the pandemic made it even worse for kids like him since he can't be with his playmates of his age i'm he's most of the time i'd just watch him play roblox or minecraft sometimes we'd watch youtube videos together can you guys suggest other meaningful activities that we can bond over other than youtube or computer games he's coming over to our house sometime this week and to be honest i don't know what activities can be done together with him we can just stick with the usual roblox minecraft or youtube but i know how short a kid's attention span can be thanks in advance 😁

so my mom is my year olds best friend and she lives hours away they really bonded this year when he would video call her during the hours i was working from home he takes her around on his ipad and stands her up and then he does things he plays lego or on the swings or whatever they talk for hours at a time she doesn't just watch though she often pretends to be an announcer when he's being physical this is it ladies and gentleman x is trying to jump from the couch to the chair can he do it will he survive and he eats it up if he's doing lego she might ask what he's building and then look up facts about something he mentions she'll shower him with info about megalodon while he's building one from lego she sings him songs or gives him suggestions of songs to ask alexa to play then watches him dance party she buys two of some coloring books and she'll color with him on the same page then they compare in the end for my son it is about having someone care what he's doing and give him that undivided attention she doesn't pepper him with questions she participates in his play she becomes a part of his world and for a kiddo who spends most of his time in someone elses world that is absolutely huge for him i hope that helps

years old son lives for his pc am i overly protective if i put parental copntrol software on his pc at this age uk my only son and months gets on his pc as soon as he gets up stays on to midnight and would stay on all night if he could get away with it he mostly plays minecraft or roblox with school friends as far as i can tell he does not; get out of his pajamas eat or drink properly do his homework or help around the house at he should be thinking for himself considering a part time job and looking ahead to balance this he has no siblings no relatives within miles and there are few kids of a similar age around those that do live locally are rarely out either going out on our bikes is 'boring ' anyway the question is how many of you think that putting qustodio or similar oh his pc at his age is reasonable what methods have you used to get them un addicted thanks
at i would have been able to get around parental controls just saying

at he should be thinking for himself considering a part time job and looking ahead bahaha sorry but i think that's more appropriate for s kids don't care about jobs at that age if you want him to get one then push for it if he wants more games or consoles make him get a part time job to pay for them look i get it i was the same way when i was his age i'd go to school then come home and get in my pjs and hop on my xbox or playstation or computer until bed time and play games he likes what he likes and you can't really change that i think bike riding is boring too hell i hate exercising i totally get it it just sounds like he needs to balance his time it isn't really healthy to be on a computer all day or playing games a job would help i don't think parental controls are going to work all he'll do is resent you and you'll be making him think he's bad for doing something he loves i'd set some restrictions if he doesn't do his chores or his homework no games if he doesn't listen to you take the computer away and tell him if he wants to buy his own computer he can get a part time job for it but what i wouldn't do is belittle or scrutinize him for behavior you've let go on i would actively help him balance family and alone time and set home expectations like chores and homework into place also if you want to get on his good side while he's doing chores ask him about the games he plays ask him what games he likes to play on roblox and what he likes building in minecraft if you show interest in what he likes i'll bet it'll make him engage in conversation hell even join in playing with him some time or watch him build in minecraft also there are some pretty funny videos of minecraft on youtube you should check some out

most kids can manage their own screen time but your son has a problem i don't think parental control software is the solution though this is going to require parenting or maybe counseling if you can't do it alone i might consider restricting his ability to use the pc until after he has handled his responsibilities i might start by moving the pc out of his room and into a common area and requiring him to earn the right to move it back he's not mature enough for unsupervised screen time

honestly i expect downvotes but i don't think video games for more than an hour a two a day are good for a developing child don't get me wrong i'm not anti video games and i love gaming myself however when my daughter is older i definitely plan on restricting use don't feel guilty about considering this you obviously have his best interest in mind i would maybe implement a you can't play until your homework chores are done when i was younger i played a lot of video games i remember my mom literally *forced me* to try out for the hs volleyball team i hated her for it at first but looking back i'm so happy she didn't let me waste my teen years sitting inside i was pretty much forced into making friends and playing outside and it was the absolute best thing for me looking back
